facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 567 of 1964 was filed by special leave

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 567 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated June 22, 1961 of Kerala High Court in A.S. No. 243 of 1955

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated June 22, 1961 of the Kerala High Court in A. S. No. 243 of 1955

facts.text: Appellants sued for redemption and recovery of suit lands alleging Exs. A-1 and B-1 created usufructuary mortgages

anchor.surface_text: The appellants sued for redemption and recovery of the suit lands alleging that Exs. A-1 and B-1 created usufructuary mortgages.

facts.text: Respondents claimed Exs. A-1 and B-1 were kanam-kuzhikanam transactions entitling them to fixing of tenure under s.21 r/w s.15 of Malabar Tenancy Act, 1929

anchor.surface_text: The respondents claimed that they were kanam-kuzhikanamdars and entitled to fixing of tenure under s. 21 read with s. 3 15 of the Malabar Tenancy Act, 1929  Madras Act 14 of 1930 .

facts.text: Trial Court upheld respondents' contention and dismissed the suit

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court upheld the respondents companyten- tion and dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Kerala High Court affirmed the decree on appeal

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Kerala High Court affirmed this decree.

facts.text: Appellants appealed to Supreme Court by special leave

anchor.surface_text: The appellants number appeal to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: During pendency of appeal, Kerala Land Reforms Act, 1963 (Act 1 of 1964) came into force

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of this appeal, the Kerala Land Reforms Act, 1963  Act 1 of 1964  came into force.

facts.text: It is common case that appeal must be disposed of in accordance with Act 1 of 1964

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon case before us that the appeal must be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of Act 1 of 1964.

facts.text: Respondents claim they are holders of kanam-kuzhikanam within meaning of s.2(23) of Act 1 of 1964

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, the respondents claim that they are the holders of kanam-kuzhikanam within the meaning of s. 2 23  of this Act.

facts.text: Ex. A-1 dated March 26, 1900

anchor.surface_text: The question in this appeal is whether Ex. A-1 dated March 26, 1900 and Ex. B-1 dated March 27, 1900

facts.text: Ex. B-1 dated March 27, 1900

anchor.surface_text: Ex. A-1 dated March 26, 1900 and Ex. B-1 dated March 27, 1900 were kanam-kuzhikanam transactions,

facts.text: Exhibits A-1 and B-1 demised the suit lands together with fruit-bearing coconut, arecanut and jack trees for 24 years

anchor.surface_text: Exhibits A-1 and B-1 demised the suit lands together with the fruit-bearing companyonut, arecanut and jack trees standing thereon for a period of 24 years.

facts.text: Transfer under Ex A-1 and B-1 was for enjoyment of lands with standing trees and planting fruit-bearing trees thereon

anchor.surface_text: The transfer was for the enjoyment of the lands with the standing trees and for the purpose of planting fruit-bearing trees thereon.

facts.text: Kanartham under Ex. A-1 was Rs. 5,000/-

anchor.surface_text: The kanam amount or the kanartham under Ex. A-1 was. Rs. 5,000/- and under Ex. B-1 was Rs. 600/-

facts.text: Kanartham under Ex. B-1 was Rs. 600/-

anchor.surface_text: under Ex. A-1 was. Rs. 5,000/- and under Ex. B-1 was Rs. 600/- . The transferees were entitled

facts.text: Transferees entitled to appropriate income of lands in lieu of interest on kanam amounts

anchor.surface_text: The transferees were entitled to appropriate the income of the lands in lieu of interest on the kanam amounts

facts.text: Transferees entitled to hold lands after expiry of 24 years until payment of kanam amounts and value of trees planted by them

anchor.surface_text: and to hold the lands even. after the expiry of 24 years until payment of the kanam amounts and the value of the trees planted by them.

facts.text: All conditions of kanam-kuzhikanam in main part of s.2(23) were satisfied by Ex A-1 and B-1

anchor.surface_text: Thus, all the companyditions of kanam-kuzhikanam mentioned in the main part of s. 2 23  were satisfied.

facts.text: Exs. A-1 and B-1 were styled kanam deeds

anchor.surface_text: Both Exs. A-1 and B-1 were styled kanam deeds.

facts.text: Exhibit A-1 stated demise was in Kettiyadakkam kanam right

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit A-1 stated that the demise was in Kettiyadakkam kanam right. Kottiadaki means took possession.

facts.text: Exhibit B-1 explicitly stated demises under Ex. A-1 and B-1 were in kanam-kuzhikanam right

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit B-1 explained Ex. A-1. Exhibit B-1 explicitly stated that the demises under Ex. A-1 and B-1 were in kanam-kuzhikanam right.

facts.text: Subsequent documents Exs. B-2, B-5, B-8, B-9, B-10 executed between 1921 and 1944 recited Exs A-1 and B-1 as kanam-kuzhikanam

anchor.surface_text: The subsequent documents, Exs. B-2, B-5, B-8, B-9, and B-10 executed between 1921 and 1944 all recited that Exs A-1 and B-1 were kanam-kuzhikanam transactions.

facts.text: Exhibits A-1 and B-1 did not contain recital showing they created security for repayment of debt

anchor.surface_text: Exhibits A-1 and B-1 did number companytain any recital showing that they created security for repayment of a debt.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with courts below that transactions were kanam-kuzhikanam and not usufructuary mortgages

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the Courts below that the transactions were kanamkuzhikanam and were number usufructuary mortgages.

facts.text: Appeal is dismissed with costs

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is dismissed with companyts.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated June 22, 1961 of the Kerala High Court in A. S. No. 243 of 1955 M . R. Gokhale and A. G. Puddissery, for the appellants. Ram Reddy, K. P. Madhava Menon and A. V. V. Nair, for respondents Nos. 2 to 13.

under s. 21 read with s. 3 15 of the Malabar Tenancy Act, 1929  Madras Act 14 of 1930 . The trial Court upheld the respondents contention and dismissed the suit. On appeal, the Kerala High Court affirmed this decree.

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 of Act 1 of 1964 gives to every tenant fixity of tenure in respect of his holding and forbids resumption of the holding except as provided in ss. 14 to 22. Section 2 is the definition section.

concepts.interpretation: Gives every tenant fixity of tenure and forbids resumption except as provided in ss.14 to 22

anchor.surface_text: By s. 2 57 , a tenant means any person who has paid or has agreed to pay rent or other consideration for his being allowed by another to possess and enjoy the land of the latter and includes inter alia a kanam-kuzhikanamdar. concepts.unlisted_description: Proving substance over form for leases

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 23  reads kanam-kuzhikanam means and includes a transfer by a landlord to another person of garden lands or of other lands or of both, with the fruit-bearing trees, if any standing thereon at the time of the transfer, for the enjoyment of those trees and for the purpose of planting such fruit-bearing trees thereon, the incidents of which transfer include-  a  a right in the transferee to hold the said lands liable for the consideration paid by him or due to him which consideration is called kanartham and  b  the liability of the transferor to pay to the transferee interest on the kanartham unless otherwise agreed to by the parties

concepts.interpretation: Transactions under Exs. A-1 and B-1 satisfied all conditions of main part

anchor.surface_text: Provided that a usufructuary mortgage as de- fined in the Transfer of Property Act, 1882  Central Act 4 of 1882 , shall not be deemed to be a kanamkuzhikanam

concepts.unlisted_description: As defined in s.58(d) Transfer of Property Act, 1882

anchor.surface_text: A kanam-kuzhikanam is a lease, and is, there- fore, a transfer of a right to enjoy the property. A mortgage is a transfer of an interest in the property for securing the repayment of a debt. The purpose of one is to enable enjoyment of the property by the transferee, that of the other is to secure the debt.

concepts.interpretation: Essential distinction applied to classify transactions as kanam-kuzhikanam (lease) not mortgage

concepts.unlisted_description: Kanam-kuzhikanam as lease for enjoyment vs mortgage for securing debt

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether a transaction is a kanam-kuzhikanam or a usufructuary mortgage, the name given to it by the parties is a relevant, though not always a decisive, consideration. If the parties described the transaction to be a kanam-kuzhikanam it is a valuable indication that they intended it to be such and not a usufructuary mortgage.

concepts.interpretation: Applied to Exs. A-1 and B-1 styled as kanam deeds and explicitly kanam-kuzhikanam

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: uctuary mortgage. If the document purports to be a mortgage, s. 12 of the Act allows the parties to prove that it is, in substance, a kanam-kuzhikanam

concepts.unlisted_label: Relevance of name given to transaction by parties
concepts.unlisted_description: Relevant but not decisive indicator of intent

anchor.surface_text: If the document purports to be a mortgage, s. 12 of the Act allows the parties to prove that it is, in substance, a kanam-kuzhikanam or other lease. But if the document purports to be or is, on its true construction, a kanamkuzhikanam or other lease, s. 12 has no application and full effect must be given to the document according to its tenor.

concepts.interpretation: Exs. A-1 and B-1 on true construction are kanam-kuzhikanam

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: uctuary mortgage. If the document purports to be a mortgage, s. 12 of the Act allows the parties to prove that it is, in substance, a kanam-kuzhikanam

concepts.unlisted_description: Full effect to tenor if lease on construction; s.12 inapplicable

arguments.claim: A kanam-kuzhikanam is a lease for enjoyment of property whereas a mortgage secures repayment of debt

anchor.surface_text: A kanamkuzhikanam and a usufructuary mortgage have many common features. ... A kanam-kuzhikanam is a lease, and is, therefore, a transfer of a right to enjoy the property. A mortgage is a transfer of an interest in the property for securing the repayment of a debt.

arguments.claim: Exhibit A-1 stated demise was in Kettiyadakkam kanam right; expression may mean usufructuary mortgage but not necessarily

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit A-1 stated that the demise was in Kettiyadakkam kanam right. Kottiadaki means took possession. The expression kettiyadakkam kanam may mean a usufructuary mortgage, but this, is not its necessary or invariable meaning.

anchor.surface_text: Significantly, the parties did not describe the transactions to be a mortgage, otti, panayam or a kyvasam panayam. Instead, they described the transactions as kanam-kuzhikanam and the amounts paid to the transferees as kanartham.

holdings.text: We agree with the Courts below that the transactions were kanamkuzhikanam and were not usufructuary mortgages.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the Courts below that the transactions were kanamkuzhikanam and were number usufructuary mortgages.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Documents styled kanam deeds with explicit kanam-kuzhikanam reference, subsequent recitals consistent, absence of debt security recital, purpose for enjoyment and planting trees aligns with lease not mortgage.

holdings.text: Thus, all the conditions of kanam-kuzhikanam mentioned in the main part of s. 2 23 were satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, all the companyditions of kanam-kuzhikanam mentioned in the main part of s. 2 23  were satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transactions involved transfer of garden lands with fruit-bearing trees for enjoyment and planting, kanartham consideration, income appropriation in lieu of interest, right to hold beyond term until repayment and tree value.

holdings.text: Exhibits A-1 and B-1 did not purport to be and were not transactions for securing debts.

anchor.surface_text: Exhibits A-1 and B-1 did number purport to be and were number transactions for securing debts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No recital creating security for debt repayment; parties used kanam-kuzhikanam terminology and kanartham, not mortgage terms like otti or panayam.

holdings.text: On the question whether a transaction is a kanam-kuzhikanam or a usufructuary mortgage, the name given to it by the parties is a relevant, though not always a decisive, consideration.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether a transaction is a kanam-kuzhikanam or a usufructuary mortgage, the name given to it by the parties is a relevant, though number always a decisive, companysideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Name provides valuable indication of intent; here documents styled kanam deeds with explicit kanam-kuzhikanam reference.

holdings.text: But if the document purports to be or is, on its true construction, a kanamkuzhikanam or other lease, s. 12 has no application and full effect must be given to the document according to its tenor.

But if the document purports to be or is, on its true companystruction, a kanamkuzhikanam or other lease, s. 12 has numberapplication

holdings.reasoning_summary: True construction of Exs. A-1 and B-1 as kanam-kuzhikanam lease based on tenor, styling, and terms; s.12 inapplicable as not purporting to be mortgage.
